title: LCM Inequality for Primes
description: Let lcm(1,...,n) denote the least common multiple of {1,...,n}. Is it true that for all k ≥ 1, lcm(1,...,p_{k+1}-1) < p_k · lcm(1,...,p_k)? Erdős and Graham call this 'almost certainly' true, but proving it requires something close to Legendre's conjecture.

overview.historicalContext: This problem explores the growth rate of the LCM function between consecutive primes. The LCM function lcm(1,...,n) is closely related to Chebyshev's ψ function, with log(lcm(1,...,n)) ~ n. The conjecture asks whether the growth between primes p_k and p_{k+1} is bounded by multiplication by p_k. Erdős and Graham described this as 'almost certainly' true, but noted the proof requires controlling prime gaps - essentially requiring Legendre's conjecture.
overview.problemStatement: Let [1,...,n] denote the least common multiple of {1,...,n}. Let p_k be the k-th prime. Is it true that for all k ≥ 1: lcm(1,...,p_{k+1}-1) < p_k · lcm(1,...,p_k)?
overview.proofStrategy: We define lcm_upto using Finset.lcm and the nth prime using Nat.nth. The main conjecture is expressed as a Prop. We verify small cases (k=1,2) computationally. The connection to Legendre's conjecture is formalized: we need to control primes q with p_k < q² < p_{k+1}.
keyInsights: Between consecutive primes, LCM only grows by composite factors (powers of smaller primes)
The key obstacle is controlling primes q where p_k < q² < p_{k+1}
Legendre's conjecture would imply at most one such q exists
Chebyshev's bounds give log(lcm(1,...,n)) ~ n asymptotically

sections.title: The LCM Function
sections.summary: Define lcm_upto and verify small values: lcm(1,...,5) = 60, etc.

sections.title: The nth Prime
sections.summary: Define nthPrime using Nat.nth and prove basic properties.

sections.title: The Main Conjecture
sections.summary: State the conjecture and explain the connection to Legendre's conjecture.

sections.title: Verified Small Cases
sections.summary: Verify the conjecture holds for k=1,2 by computation, plus Chebyshev asymptotic.

conclusion.summary: We formalize Erdős Problem #458 about the growth of LCM between consecutive primes. The conjecture remains open because proving it requires controlling prime gaps, essentially requiring Legendre's conjecture. Small cases are verified computationally.
conclusion.implications: This connects the fine structure of LCM growth to deep questions about prime distribution. A proof would have implications for understanding how composite numbers fill gaps between primes.
openQuestions: Can the conjecture be proved unconditionally for sufficiently large k?
What is the relationship to the Riemann Hypothesis?
